messages: 002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I guess you know that HTML 5 parser sometimes gives adjacent text nodes?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:32): 002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570: by design based on ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c's spec feedback, right?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:33): looks like the xmlns:prefix discussion triggered a flurry of tweets...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:33): http://twitter.com/shelleypowers
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:36): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: <b>Test</i>Test should still give one text node, no?
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:37): (Or am I missing which feedback you meant?)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:38): hmm. that one might be a bug per spec
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:38): That is a bug per spec, as there is no node inserted by the parser between those two character tokens
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:39): FWIW: http://gsnedders.html5.org/html5lib-tests/runner.html
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (16:40): (Which works more cross-browser than http://html5.org/parsing-tests/testrunner.htm for me)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:48): <audio style=display:inline>hello</audio>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:49): maybe audio should be display:none !important in the ua style sheet (like noscript)?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:50): audio:not([controls]) that is
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:13): what's the use case for createImageData(imagedata) again?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:13): afaict it's just convenience for createImageData(imagedata.width, imagedata.height)
66b0d785bfa15d051888c24dabba7342 (17:14): with some added confusion (hey this might a copy constructor!)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:25): I wonder if these are the sorts of rules that make the guys building CSS engines wince for their performance:
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:25): #faqs-by-section input.lang-chooser.en-US:checked ~ dl ul.entries > li:not(.en-us)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:29): could have been worse; at least you used a child selector

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (17:56): So there are rumors of a document containg all the IDL from all web specs. Does anyone know where it is? Or is there some other way of finding out a comprehensive list of all objects that should implement a given interface
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:00): I think I asked about this before, but I'll ask again - I got a request for a German-speaking presenter to speak at an event in Berlin on September 14
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:00): presentation about HTML5
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:00): any recommendations?
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:04): Coincidently, I may happen to be in Berlin then. I do not, however, speak German. (Nor, for that matter, am I any good at presenting in any language.)
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (18:04): I got a request, too. On Oct 29 in Tokyo, though.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:06): 002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570: just wing it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:06): you can learn german by setting your bugzilla locale preferences to "de"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:06): it's that simple
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:06): I have it on good authority that if you just sound like a monster screaming into a staticky walkietalkie while underwater, German people will understand you.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): That's Danish
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): wonders if WebIDL will be updated to use ES5 terminology
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:08): Interesting.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:09): if you ever get a chance to hear a Norwegian person imitating a Danish person, I recommend grabbing that chance
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:12): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s-mOy8VUEBk
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:17): knowing neither Danish nor Norwegian
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:17): 99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e: what is the October event?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:17): I can honestly say that what I got out of it was "Norwegians poking fun at Danes"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:17): I also got "people over there talk funny".
99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e (18:18): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the one in Ginza, CSS Nite
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:18): But I said it to myself in a thick Texan drawl, so I don't think I really get much from that.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (18:18): 99d799105c5630cb16b3a7b54e6ae26e: so you going to do it?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: You can't disturb me much when I'm not actually looking at IRC for 23 hours
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I could hunt you down and disturb you
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:21): I just chose not to
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:21): I guess a good US analogue is Southerners poking fun at Harvard graduates
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:21): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I guess there's some buffering and you'd need to flush it, perhaps by closing the thingy, or something, I don't know really
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:21): "I go to Hahvahd, so I can't say an ah'
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:21): goes away again
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:21): wonders where away is, in case he needs to track ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79cdown
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:21): Oh, if paul_irish reads IRC logs then he should probably email comments to me
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (18:22): (I have secret communication channels with b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, obviously.)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:23): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: Yeah, that's probably right.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:23): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: It seems quite common in scandinavia to be bemused by Danish pronounciation. It seems like it is actually quite odd and not _just_ people taking the piss for other people taking differntley
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:23): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: Though we like making fun of people from Minnesota more.  They talk *really* funny.
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:23): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hahvahd... that actually redirects to Harvard
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:23): e.g. apparently the language is changing so fast that you can identify when expats left denmark from their voice alone
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:25): the biggest thing I know about those people is that they call soda "pop"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:26): They have an "ae"/"ah" swap somewhat ("I'll get a baeg of bahgels"), and stretch their "o" into a long "oo".  "I'm from Minnesooota."
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:27): I spent a few weeks touring Europe with a group of minnesotans.  Much hilarity ensued.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:27): Unfortunately for them I'm from Houston, which homogenizes my accent into basically American Standard with a touch of drawl.
